Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: SusChEM: Hybrid Nanoparticles of the Copper Sulfides
Award.AbstractNarration:
Janet E Macdonald from Vanderbilt University is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Sustainable Chemistry, Engineering and Materials (SusChEM) initiative to pursue research into the preparation of new photocatalysts based on nanoparticles of the family of copper sulfides. The research aims to develop shape and size controlled syntheses to new and underexplored phases of the copper sulfides, and to gain a fundamental understanding of their crystallographic structures and photoluminescence phenomena. Syntheses of hybrid metal-semiconductor nanoparticles of the copper sulfides will also be developed and studied for their photoinduced charge separation and application towards photocatalytic water splitting to give H2 gas.

These syntheses and new nanoparticles will facilitate the study of advanced photocatalyst design, and the building of stable, active, non-toxic, viable photocatalysts for green fuel generation from solar energy. The educational goals of this CAREER award is in part to integrate the research into outreach programs to Tennessee middle and high school students through the Vanderbilt Summer Academy and the Vanderbilt Students Volunteer for Science, thereby encouraging economically disadvantaged and underrepresented groups into careers in the physical and material sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the world is threatened by climate change, there is increasing pressure to develop new green technologies and decrease America?s carbon footprint. One such technology is to develop fuels from solar power. While solar energy technology is more commonly used to directly power homes and businesses with electricity, solar-to-fuel technology has the possibility of replacing fossil fuels for heating and transportation. One of the most attractive alternative fuels is hydrogen, which can be obtained from splitting water molecules its components, hydrogen and oxygen. The hydrogen can then be used to power cars, heating factories and in other combustion engines with only water as its by-product. However, it is energy intensive to create hydrogen, so by leveraging solar energy to make it, the whole process becomes carbon neutral.

Using sunlight to split water was first reported in the 1970s though materials called photocatalysts, but despite decades of effort, the efficiencies have remained stubbornly low. The goal is to create a solar panel that can easily and efficiently produce hydrogen by splitting water molecules. A major problem with these panels is the materials, or crystals, used in them. The large, micron-sized, crystals of light-capturing material are generally not very efficient. However, with nano-sized crystals, some of the most troublesome steps in in the water splitting process become more much more efficient. Exciting as this is, the unfortunate reality is that the commonly studied cadmium-based nanocrystals are not practical as photocatalysts; they contain toxic cadmium and tend to break down under the conditions used for water splitting. In contrast, the family of copper sulfides and mixed metal copper sulfides represent very promising alternatives.

The goal of this project was to discover the fundamental synthetic principles to the preparation of high quality copper sulfide and mixed-metal copper sulfide nanoparticles and their metal-semiconductor hybrids to facilitate advanced photocatalyst design for water splitting.

We made several advancements in the synthesis of CuInS2 (the most likely CdS replacement) and specifically a crystalline phase that has only been formed at nanoscale. We discovered why this special phase forms under certain conditions, studied the structure through atomic resolution electron microscopy to understand exactly how the copper and indium atoms are ordered in the crystals. The material glows in a very uncommon way: at wavelengths in the infra-red region of the spectrum of light.  We performed calculations to determine the atomic source of that emission so that we could learn to improve the strength of the emission.

One of the most challenging aspects of this project was the discovery that how the method of how he nanocrystals of Cu2S and CuInS2 were made seemed to changed their properties- in the unexpected way that adding the flour to sugar versus the sugar to the flour might completely change the cookies from crunchy to chewy. Nanocrystals are prepared with a protective coat of organic molecules called ligands. Depending on the synthesis route, the same types of ligands had completely different binding strengths. We hypothesized why (they were bound to more or fewer copper atoms on the surface) and were able to exploit this knowledge of the strong binding to demonstrate the implications to synthesis: we prepared nano-sized rods of Cu2S instead of the usual spheres. We also showed that this stronger binding mode made for more stable and more efficient photocatalysts than photocatalysts that had the weak binding ligands.

Light-absorbing nanocrystals work best as photocatalysts when there are small domains of metals attached to the surface. We developed ways to grow these metals on the surfaces of the nanocrystals paying close attention again to how the ligand coats were influencing this processes.

This grant funded the tuition and stipend of three graduate students, and helped fund some of the material and analysis costs of several others on this project (whose tuition and stipends were supplied through other mechanisms). Ten publications in peer reviewed journals resulted, including high impact journals such as Nature Communications, ACS Nano, and Chemistry of Materials.  

Graduate students on this project became deeply involved with outreach programs to teach science lessons to schools in rural Tennessee as part of the Vanderbilt Student Volunteers for Science. The primary investigator developed two laboratories for visiting rising high school freshmen in the Vanderbilt Summer Academy program. The graduate students and PI hosted the academy students in our laboratory annually. One of the laboratories is being adapted for the outreach Vanderbilt Student Volunteers for Science program so it may go directly into Tennessee schools.
